verses.text: It was reported to Holofernes, the commander of the Assyrian army, that the people of Israel had prepared for war, had shut up every mountain pass, fortified all the high places, and laid obstacles in the valleys.
verses.comment: Israel's preparations recall earlier times when God enabled them to resist powerful enemies. The mention of mountain passes also alludes to Israel's strategic use of terrain in the conquest of Canaan.

verses.text: He was enraged and called together all the rulers of Moab, the commanders of Ammon, and all the governors of the western coast.
verses.comment: Holofernes gathers together various neighboring nations, indicating the serious threat the Israelites posed, and showing the unity among Israel’s enemies.

verses.text: He said to them, 'Tell me, you sons of Canaan, who are these people living in the hill country? What is their strength, and who leads them? Why have they refused to come out and meet me?'
verses.comment: Holofernes demands intelligence about Israel, recognizing their resolve and independence, echoing ancient antagonism between Canaanites and Israelites.

verses.text: 'Where do they come from, and what kind of people are they, that have dared to resist me?'
verses.comment: The pride and arrogance of pagan kings toward God’s people is a common biblical theme (see Isaiah 36:4-15).

verses.text: Achior, the leader of all the Ammonites, replied, 'Let my lord listen. I will tell you the truth about these people who dwell in the hill country nearby.'
verses.comment: Achior stands out as a non-Israelite who speaks truth about God’s people, a motif seen in Rahab (Josh. 2) and the magi (Matt. 2:1-12).

verses.text: 'These people are descendants of the Chaldeans.'
verses.comment: Achior summarizes Israel’s ancestry, grounding their history in Abraham's call from Ur of the Chaldeans.

verses.text: 'They lived there for a time and then migrated to Mesopotamia, because they did not wish to follow the gods worshiped by their fathers in Chaldea.'
verses.comment: Israel's distinctive monotheism led them to leave home, typifying the call to holiness and separation (Lev. 20:26).

verses.text: 'They abandoned the ways of their ancestors and worshiped the one God of heaven, whom they came to know. As a result, they were driven away from the presence of their gods, and migrated to Canaan and lived there.'
verses.comment: Achior expresses Israel’s unique commitment to monotheism and divine revelation. The movement to Canaan foreshadows later pilgrimages in salvation history.

verses.text: 'When a famine struck them, they left Canaan for Egypt and settled there as long as they could. Their numbers grew greatly, and they became a large population.'
verses.comment: This is a concise summary of Joseph’s story and the multiplication of Israel in Egypt.

verses.text: 'But the Egyptians oppressed them until they cried out to their God, who struck the Egyptians with plagues of death.'
verses.comment: The Exodus is referenced here, highlighting both God’s power to save and His judgment upon the nations.

verses.text: 'So the Israelites left Egypt and God dried up the Red Sea for them, and led them on the way to Sinai and Kadesh Barnea. They expelled all who lived in the desert.'
verses.comment: Links to the crossing of the Red Sea, and the theme of divine guidance. The conquest of the wilderness prefigures spiritual trials.

verses.text: 'Then they settled in the land of the Amorites, destroyed by their strength all inhabitants of Heshbon, and crossed the Jordan to take possession of all the hill country.'
verses.comment: The inheritance of Israel through battle echoes God’s promise and the journey into the land, both literal and spiritual.

verses.text: 'There they resided as long as they did not sin against their God; for when they did sin, they were delivered into the hands of invading kings, into captivity and exile.'
verses.comment: Achior identifies that obedience brings blessing and sin brings judgment, an eternal theme in God’s covenant.

verses.text: 'But when they repented and returned to their God, He brought them back from exile, for their God is merciful and never forsakes them so long as they obey Him.'
verses.comment: The cycle of repentance and restoration prefigures themes fulfilled in Christ (Luke 15:18-24) and the sacramental life of the Church, with mercy always available.

verses.text: 'Now, they have returned to their God, and have come back from the places where they were scattered, and have occupied Jerusalem, where their sanctuary is, and have settled in the hill country, for it was left deserted.'
verses.comment: This rebuilding and return to worship foreshadows the restoration of true religious practices and the ongoing presence of God among his people.

verses.text: 'So now, my master and lord, if these people are sinning against their God, and we catch them at this, they will fall, and their God will give them up to you, and you will overcome them.'
verses.comment: Achior recognizes the principle of divine justice: persistent sin leads to defeat. This relates to the need for sacramental confession and continual conversion.

verses.text: 'But if they are not guilty and are obedient, then let my lord pass them by, lest their God defend them, and we become a laughingstock to the whole world.'
verses.comment: The idea that God fights for His people recalls many biblical episodes (see 2 Chron. 20:15). This trust prefigures the defense and protection promised to Christ’s Church.

verses.text: When Achior had finished speaking, all the chieftains of Holofernes grew angry, and they threatened to kill him.
verses.comment: Opposition to God’s messengers by pagan powers is a frequent motif, paralleling prophets’ experiences (Jer. 26:11).

verses.text: They said, 'We are not afraid of the Israelites. See! They are a people without strength or power. We will overcome them easily.'
verses.comment: Goliath’s confidence was similarly misplaced. The real strength of Israel lies in God’s favor, not in numbers or might.

verses.text: The governors of the coastlands and Moab, together with the generals, insisted, 'Let Achior be taken to Bethulia and handed over to the Israelites. Let him see their destruction with his own eyes.'
verses.comment: Achior, like Joseph, is sent to God's people as a non-Israelite witness; his fate is intertwined with Israel’s deliverance.

verses.text: At this, the people clamored fiercely, and demanded Achior’s death so that the Israelites would be filled with terror and give up their resistance.
verses.comment: This type of intimidation is seen in the historical persecutions of true worshippers, and those who speak for God often inspire both fear and hatred.

verses.text: But Holofernes declared to Achior in the presence of all, 'You will not be harmed until we return from battle. Then we will deal with you as victorious over Israel.'
verses.comment: Holofernes temporarily spares Achior, demonstrating pride and presumption, common in pagan kings when set against the destiny of God’s people.

verses.text: Then Holofernes ordered his men to take Achior to Bethulia and hand him over to the Israelites.
verses.comment: Transition to Bethulia sets the stage for the coming deliverance. Achior’s presence among the Israelites serves as an image of conversion and integration into the true worshipping community.

verses.text: So the servants seized Achior, led him out of the camp into the plain, and left him near Bethulia; and they returned to their master.
verses.comment: Achior’s isolation prefigures many biblical conversions where faith is tested in solitude before the Lord’s providence brings about reconciliation and integration.
